sore. incl. a scrape or burn.
unripe ondoshibii berries, not yet edible
stuff, possessions, now(?) generally understood to refer to beads
a variant pronunciation of akho ‘genitals’ and akho ‘I dunno’.
skin. Pl ~ of pl animals.(no pl.) honey in the big holes, covered.
sp. plant; a bit like a small ng’ang’a (a thick trunk w/o much in the way of leaves) about a foot tall which has a large deep red fruit the size of an apple. Homonym w ‘urine’ below.

his or her grandmother or grand-aunt, with any number of ‘greats’; by extension, (great) grand-daughter, grand-niece. Default reading is higher generation; the inverse Bantu reading requires a disambiguating context.(1) grandfather, grand-uncle, with any number of ‘great’s. (FaFa, FaFaBr, MoFa, MoFaBr, etc.)(2) maternal uncle (older or younger than mother). (MoBr)(3) grandson, grandnephew, with any number of ‘greats’ (Bantu inverse of (1). Also sororal nephew, inverse of (2).)‘Grandfather’ is default reading; reading of ‘grandson’ requires a disambiguating context. Can be used in the vocative for any of the three relationships.
1) grandfather, grand-uncle, with any number of ‘great’s.
butt, tako, rungu (of a person, stick, etc.)
(no VH) male genitals [everything; pl ~ of 2 people].
(1) his/her/their(great) grandfather, grand-uncle, & maternal uncle(2) by extension,his/her/their (great) grandson, grandnephew.
(1) eye;(2) the bit of sinew twisted into the leading end of gunny-sack thread so it can be threaded through small beads
the big Lappet tumbusi vulture, per Brian.
his/her/their son, daughter, nephew, or niece; also grandson etc. Likely also son/daughter-in-law, per etymology and Berger Weyeweyeko 81.
female, human or animal (cf. yaggamba); girl, woman, any age: newborn to grandmother.
the sinews running down the spine

(1) grandmother, grand-aunt, with any number of ‘great’s.(2) grand-daughter, grand-niece, with any number of ‘great’s. ‘Grandmother’ is default reading; a Bantu-like inverse reading of ‘granddaughter’ requires a disambiguating context.
the Klip Dagga / lion’s ear, Leonotis nepetifolia (mint family)to be fine, well, mzima.

generic term for brother-, sister-, or cousin-in-law (see agishewu, hazaye-ko, nithame/nithako-ko.) a broader use than in English: used for siblings-in-law of one’s siblings (brother of one’s wife, brother of one’s sister’s husband, etc.), but cannot be used for two degrees of marriage, where ‘brother/sister/cousin’ is used again.
(1) south. (2) a country where the Hadza of old lived. cf. sanzako.
caracal, Caracal caracal. A lynx, with tufted ears.

sp. tree, mpome nyeupe/kubwa (Onkai). The common yellow/white highly papery-barked tree (one of the biggest trees away from water) with twigs like thorns (they seem to end in thorns). Perhaps a Commiphora sp.?
(1) leg(s), including feet.(2) longs legs, as water birds, antelope, etc.
father-in-law or son-in-law (same as site, but masc. only)
spirits of the ancestors, from your parents to the remote past. (may be prayed to, celebrated, sacrificed to; may bother or possess the living, causing them illness or to act crazy.)
waist/hips (from the hip joint to the waist) pl is pl people; for sg ‘a hip’ use papasa etc.
heart, of person or animal. just an organ, not where you think or feel. for that, use nkoro-ko.
eyelash(es). fsg is not collective, only a single lash.
fat with only a little meat
whiskers (as on a cat, lion, etc.), beard, moustache [not seen on Hadza]
a small axe designed for getting honey (blade fits into hole in handle). Blades are iron, made by the camp smith.
rain, river (an arroyo when full of water); also the rainy season masika. (2)  the ante
his/her/their brother, sister, or cousin. Cf. mizzi.
a boil or abscess. a swelling w white smelly puss that leaves a hole (abato).
gourd, ukibuyu, esp. if short & round. Used to hold water.
upper lip, both vermillion and area of moustache & philtrum as in English.
mother or aunt, also step-mother, or mother of sibling-in-law of sibling-in-law (site(ko) can only be used through one degree of marriage).
(1) -bee [geo] Pleiades (2) [bug] Sands: pond skater (sp. water bug)ay! ow! (for minor pains). Said by old women when sitting down.
Isaya & Mariam: pin-tailed whydah msese mweupe, fumbwe, Vidua macroura; probably also breeding male bishops and widowbirds (esp. Euplectis jacksoni if local).
Pa! a vocative form of bawa father:
honey (covered, in the small holes-brood chamber; sg ~ honey of 1 hive, pl ~ honey of several), also the generic term for ‘honey’ (as in ‘honey is important food’).
how a woman addresses her father, pat. uncle, or father-in-law. voc & ref.
a generic term for father or paternal uncle (either older or younger).
hole, burrow, etc. A hole in the ground (burrow), a hole through s.t., as a board or a bead. (For a hole in (not through) wall, or a pit in a board
sp. bee (doesn’t sting, fairly small, only produces a handful of honey)
a hunchback, or the (masc.) hump of a hunchback
big warthog [masc. only, per Mom] Also a little hill just south-west of Yaeda which had a camp in Obst’s day
The Baray, the largest river (an arroyo) in the region of Mangola, recently larger and more seasonal due to forest clearing by Datooga upstream. Not Hadza name.
salt panCommon word for Lake Eyasi when dry.
bald head (sg is half bald, pl completely bald)
Sighting/hunting name for a zebra. no fem. or pl suffixes; used as interjection or w copula.
thumb or big toe, finger or toe nail, or claw. Sg ~ thumb or big toe or its nail; pl ~ the other finger- or toe-nails excepting the thumb / big toe, or two thumbs / big toes.
a place name (Lake Basotu per Malloy)
a knobby brown bead made from a seed, or a necklace made of them.
(1) father; paternal uncle (either older or younger than father).(2) informal term for a man, even at 25 yrs (but you’d only call s.o. you know bâwa).
elephantLoxodonta africana. (sg or collective). An epeme animal.
the call of a large white dlapo ‘dove’.
(first) a large uzame spotted hyena; (later) the muzumi striped hyena [both Isaya]
wildebeest, gnuonnochaetes taurinus. An epeme animal
(1)[not coll] (first) Isanzu name for uzame, spotted hyena. Sands has this meaning. (later) the tubaba aardwolf. Eats termites. (2) voracious (of a hyena)
(1)Sighting/hunting name of naggoma-ko buffalo (from film; M d n rec). See hâtu. (2) bobo, -ko, -biitsetse fly? horsefly? Biggest biting fly. Hurts a lot.
Kampala’s variant of pushashi gall bladder.
(1) cattle egret (or buff-backed heron)(2) Sands: also a small, white insect (fly?); not reconfirmed, but it was offered up spontaneously.
a scar, whether from a burn or cut, accidental or decorative, but not tlakubii cuts on the cheeks.

fish(any kind, though there are few large species, perhaps only Oreochromis amphimelas tilapia, Clarias air-breathing catfish, and Protopterus lungfish). Not considered a ‘serious’ word by M. (Used often by children, seldom by adults. No ‘serious’ equivalent.)
louse(either head or pubic lice, sg or coll.)
white hair(s). Sg ~ coll. Pl for 2 or 3 hairs.
fish. [see ccama.]fetus (before it is old enough to start kicking around (up to 1–2 months; after that it is ora)

fetus (before it is old enough to start kicking around (up to 1–2 months; after that it is ora)small intestines. Same as zzikisibii.to reheat(2nd-plus heating only).lymph glands in neck, or swelling in neck.nude (not wearing clothes).the call of the tiggiri-ko honey-guide. [not a verb]to go in a large group (to gather berries, to move camp, go to town, etc.)to  kiss. See cca. Same as ccoo look down into or at, to peer down, as into a ravine.Sands: duiker funo (generic name; told all duikers are the same). (Miller got ‘like zzezzee-ko, with same color but smaller’.)a camp of many people: a cluster of ccezzabee. tickM: the red-billed firefinch, Lagonosticta senegala. Isaya denies this, using only Bantu (t)sunta-ko for theseSee cceggê to peer down. the call of the rufous-napedlark, Mirafra africana; Isaya forgets its actual name. to drop, of rain.sprinkle, to drip many drops, but normally ‘to rain’.no do, io. Atibi hiccikwaiphii, hiccikwaami; -hV hab. adj to be dripping (of to collect (firewood) doto look atacid burp, reflux, ?heartburnwhen chungu hurts your throat. Often get from eating thafabee. to squeeze through (a tight opening)~ ccezza, -kocamp, hut.to kiss (lips on lips, on cheek, etc.) do oblig
lymph glands in neck, or swelling in neck.
Sands: duiker funo (generic name; told all duikers are the same). (Miller got ‘like zzezzee-ko, with same color but smaller’.)
a camp of many people: a cluster of ccezzabee.
M: the red-billed firefinch, Lagonosticta senegala. Isaya denies this, using only Bantu (t)sunta-ko for these
the call of the rufous-napedlark, Mirafra africana; Isaya forgets its actual name.
acid burp, reflux, ?heartburnwhen chungu hurts your throat. Often get from eating thafabee.

sunbirdsscarlet-chested sunbird (also ID’d from pic for scimitar bill, which is larger). [M feels this is probably mimetic from their call, and is only coincidentally ‘a hug’, rather than the birds being called ‘kissers’, but they just sound like many other small birds.] to be full; w DO to fill
a sp. small tree w/o thorns, flowers, fruit (no use)
The Eastern Tiger Snake / Striped Cat Snake
a scar, an accidental cut which has healed over.
baobab seed(s) [no coll], whether collected fresh or salvaged from baboon shit in times of hunger.
(1)sp. large tree, light-colored bark, thorns.(2)~ sâa-koduck
a threshing floor: a large flat rock that women sit on while working.
sp. Vigna (?), with an edible root similar to xxekwa. Limited to the hills NE of Mangola town, from the town itself & for several km.
neck. fem. for antelope, people, most birds (Sands had masc for human neck; either for neck meat)

aa: cikirîngca, cikiringcingca, cikingca, cikinga, cikirinza, cikinza, -bii
pinkie fingerttle toe. A playful word w multiple variants.
dwarfmongoose , Helogale parvula undulata. Social. Lives in groups, likes to eat chickens.
papyrusCyperus papyrus. Coll. (pl for 2 or 3; use sg if too many to count.)
skin or cloth wrapped around a poison arrowhead and tang or zzi’atoko
Sighting/hunting name for zebra. (Cf. bashu, gidabashu) [VH optional. Like other hunting names, M has never heard this in the fem.]
One who comes and goes, and comes and goes quickly.twin, twins [told this is Iraqw, not Hadza. Cf. slangayo.]

white korongo stork, Ciconia ciconia [Isaya, M, Brian]; the yellow-billed stork yangeyange mkubwa, Mycteria ibis, often also ID’d as this. Daudi: both species are called daradara, though people recognize the difference. He’s always heard [l].
a strip zebra leather worn just below knee (in KL). (just decoration) [E: deranda]
an owl[Cf. Dat. digashi sp. bird which flies up from tree to tree, calling.]See bashu
place name, where one can get rerako meerschaum [only one place called this]
drum, used only for tourists. not part of Hadza culture. Named for the ‘word’ called out at the end of playing: dênke! [M 1st wrote as ?tinki.]
same as qquburu – s.o. w a badly healed bone.
young woman, from maitoko until marriage. [no masc]. Does not imply virginity. Crittenden (pc): female juvenile. Cf. erati.
dust, in air or on ground. (no -bee) Also used for dandruff.
a tree, no fruit, wood is preferred for mise-ko fire-drills. Resembles ondoshi? Found in Olpiro, wood transported to Mangola.
pus (yellow stinky pus in a wound, also white stinky gunk in a boil)

minor edible fruit & tree [eaten, but not important] fem. -ko, -bee trees; masc dlema, -bii the fruit. Leaves chartreuse; upper surface feels rough, grabs finger if you rub it.  [not same as dlema’o-ko.]
sp. cordia? One of several minor food berries that resemble & are commonly called ondoshibi. not the same as zzima’o. (M d n know gender diff, only guesses it’s fruit vs tree.) [no V harmony w -bii]
(1)the Iraqw(2)tree & its fruit; look like slukwaae-bee
sp. bug that travels in trails to eat rotting meat. Sands: looks like a pill bug (but flatter), eats the flesh off bones
sp. cordia? One of several minor food berries that resemble & commonly called ondoshi. they may all have similar red gooseberry-blossom-like flowers
a cloth worn as clothing, often around chest, but also skirt or headscarf
a short stone pipe, length & width of three fingers together.
ejaculate, from man or woman (white, not just being wet)
a leguminous vine, Vigna macrorhyncha (Vincent 1985). Mangola name; called slaake-ko in Yaeda.
the largest Hadza habitation in Tlhiika. [M not sure if this is a Hadza name]
zebra(f) one of the principal large game species and an epeme animal. Local sp. is Grant’s zebra,
short-beaked fish-eating birds : heron, bittern, kingfisher.
the name of a place with musical rocks [just one place. Not cog. w dundui per M.]
(1) a short blunt dull knife used by women to cut roots etc.; same knife as itlako, but name indicates it’s used by women. (2) something poking out (as from under skin).
distended stomach (from malnutrition) [used as nickname for kid w such]; kind of bird (named for its big stomach)
sand-grouse firigogo (1997: those w black on their faces: yellow-throated & black-faced occur in TZ, Pterocles gutturalis & P. decoratus). Not the same as konkorokwiye, gugurugugwaye, etc.
Sands: bat-eared fox, same as biriri-ko, w a good pic.
tree, wood used to make xxanako shafts (Grewia flavescens per Kew; G. platyclada per EAH – Woodburn 1970).

(1) narrow (monocot) leaf.(2) grass (general term). Local grass sp. are Diplachne fusca and Sporobolus spicatus, with the sedge Cyperus laevigatus in boggy areas; per KL also Themeda triandra red oat grass.
Endamaghay, the largest Hadza habitation in Mangora. At the northern end of the lake. Not a Hadza name.
&M: the hooded vulture tumbusi mdogo, Necrosyrtes monachus; also name of a river.
Wild ‘Sisal’ ~ Sword Sansevieria, Sansevieria ehrenbergii. Used to roof huts, or implanted on perimeter to shore up wall.
young man (grown up but not married). Marlowe: an adult of either sex; epeme man. Crittenden (p.c.): male juvenile.
Eyasi, the large soda lake around which the Hadza live. Fed by the Sibiti river in the south, the Barai in Mangola,  both of which run dry, and a few smaller streams.
a switch used to punish children
storehouse, granary. (Hadza do not use these)
Egyptian cobraOne of four deadly snakes in Hadza country
M’s form of kâsha-bii. [M has [aː] for gâshabii but [aa] for kâshabii.]
an alt. name for the ggutako water terrapin, used by Zeke. Yaeda only? [not Isanzu, not recognized by M., pl unknown]
cheek(s), side(s) of face.  Griscom got for ‘cheekbone’.
Opilia sp. (O. campestris [Marlowe]) Tree/shrub with a pencil eraser–sized fruit; vaguely laurel-shaped leaves, but rounder.
Aloe vera, or at least an aloe [ID’d live in the yard]
sternum and flesh around this area (breast area).
sp. Balaria (also other plants?) (a family of plants that includes the one with the 5-petaled peach-colored flowers whose bark is used for fever medicine. It has thorns.)
Fischer’s lovebird, Agapornis fischeri (local); used for pics of kasuku ‘parrot’ in general, though none occur here.

Pancake tortoise, Malacochersus tornieri, which lives among rocks. Chelonians are considered to be beasts (kharimo) rather than crawlies (kinja), perhaps because they are eaten like beasts. (but cf. also Bantu)
sp. bird. (Mom, Ankiya) (alt of khoromonko hornbill?)
bare-faced go-away bird, Corythaixoides. [Sands, Isaya, Brian]. Not in the area per Helm’s, but hard to misidentify as it’s a distinctive bird.

pubis, male or female. the area with hair below the stomach (for the Hadza that even have pubic hair. called zzambiye gguda when no hair on an adult) [everyone busted up laughing when I read this one off]
the leopard tortoise, Geochelone pardalis; with a domed back. (Spek’s hinged tortoise, Kinixys spekii, may also be a local species.)

turtle/terrapin (locally a side-necked water turtle; the neck and living in the water are both distinguishing characteristics for the Hadza). The local species is the marsh terrapin, Pelomedusa subrufa.
courtyard: the place people sit outside, under the trees, usually on skins, around the fire for men or by themselves for the women
Sighting/hunting name of dongo-ko zebra. Cf. basho
a gift a husband gives parents-in-law after wife gets pregnant or has kids
peg ladder: a series of pegs pounded into a baobab trunk to climb it (e.g. for honey). same as xoxokobee.
seasonal pond or lake. small pond, normally with clear water.
(1992) striped grass rat, or striped mouse, the one with 3 stripes on its back?
(a place name) a large Hadza camp in Sipunga.
beaded arm or leg bands (especially arm bands)
twisted strand of beads worn originally at the waist, but now at the neck as well.
an axe for cutting into tree trunks to get at beehives; blade set in-line with the handle, like a root cutter in the West.
(1) flamingo (2) the sound made by baby hornbills in Berger’s Weyeweye.
the large blood vessel(s) of the neck; pl also the pulse in the neck
a loser, person failing to marry, succeed (+adj); lazy person [E: Bantu?]
mane(s) of lion, eland, zebra, gnu, etc.

the Budahaya / Udahaya River, the largest in Siponga. Passes just south of Mangora and feeds the Yaeda Swamp. Orig. larger than Barai but not the size of the Sibiti. Not much water anymore, as it is diverted upstream in the Mbulu Highlands for agriculture. Gallery forest northern end; rock shelters in its steep banks are center of the dry season habitation of Sipunga.
warthog warts (other endings are not ok)
gift given by parent to s.o. courting their child.
cupping hornplaced over sore or swelling and sucked through end to remove damu chafu
elbow(s). same as ccukuccukudabee [note irregular gender, msg but fpl.] [de Voogt gotsugusugûda; Griscom got fem. of same for ‘inside of elbow’][gusuda. Cf. Dat. gurunguruda ‘elbow’]
Daudi (at Sengele), Maria:  white-backed vulture, Gyps africanus. I&M: palm-nut vulture
people of long ago that used clubs and ran to hunt.
alt. name wild dog, mbugida. M: on the large side. [Bleek ⟨hadebipi⟩]
Acacia stuhlmannii (shrub, velvety pods) per W 1970, EAH.
(1) ear of maize, or grain of maize ?(2) ~ hogo Balanites ‘desert date’, as recorded in KL (⟨hagua⟩for fruit). hagu?
Sands: adolescent animal. [Cf. Datooga hawanika ‘young female calf after puberty’; Marta: Datooga haɣwanda young cow before giving birth; Kießling: hàqwáandà ‘calf’]
(1)an alt. word for cattle. (2)the tubaba aardwolf. Sands got this as the only word for aarwolf; ID’d w clear photo, rec’d as striped, eats termites, etc. [also per Swynnerton]
medicine (1) arrow poison (2) protective eland-horn charm(3) witch, doctor [not a Hadza occupation], witchcraft
an animal skin worn over the shoulder and around the waist, like a toga, for men or women [~ Marlowe’s kaross?]‘and then they …’Seeha-.
a tree w white papery bark, thorns, ≈ like the angaruma used for fire-drills. Often has beehives. E: it has edible gum.
(1) a rock, stone (such as a hammerstone; normal word for stones), seed. (2) seed. Griscom could only get haqqako for ‘seed’. See tetere.
blind person to continue to insist, beg, etc. See nqajja.
tracks (hoof marks from running animals)let him by! etc. (to move out of the way, to let pass.)
a young lion, a half-grown lion.
sp. bird that flies noisily overhead at night; M d n know what it looks like. [pl for 2–3, sg/coll for many.] [Cf. Iraqw hale/ ‘pelicans’]
admirative names for atcekako cattle, such as when one sees an impressive herd
Sighting/hunting name for naggomako buffalo [amurmur (hahatu) is difficult to hear cuz of the init. h, but M believes it is there.] See bobo.
a really old person. See xxaggatca.
(1) the Pleiadespl only; would be strange to use sg for one of them). (2) an insect that swims underwater, rests on the bottom,

(1) human being(2) esp. a Hadza (current default reading out of context).(3) In Berger Haine, when God creates the animals, the dongoko zebra is a haza, but the lion and leopard are xhaano ‘dog’; all are exiled as kharimo ‘beasts’.
beard (used for people or warthog; not sure about other animals) ~ mungurongoti-ko.
broad (dicot) leaves (green, not dry). (cf. ena). also bark, paper [sheet or sheaf, but not scattered papers. Bleek had this for ‘book’.]
lower leg bones (fibula and tibia), or lower arm bones (radius and ulna); also lower leg, but not lower arm.
(male speaker) male kin of ego’s generation. brother (full, half, step) or male cousin, or (fictive kinship?) brother-in-law of a sibling-in-law.
integument: smaller pieces of tree bark on tree or on ground, skin of fruit (baobab or orange),
Isaya for the Variable & Striped skinks.

ashaft-arrow, barbed or knurled: an extra-long sharpened arrow shaft, without poison or an attached arrowhead, used to hunt birds, bats, rabbits, hyrax, occasionally dikdik. Were previously used w poison.
harvester termite Eat leaves, not wood; a large species, seen collecting grass off paths during the day.
Acacia sp. (Xanthophloea?) (fever tree?, Naivasha thorn? ) [a white-green barked acacia?]
the ‘desert date’, BalanitesSeveral similar trees with long thick green spines and thin-skinned yellow edible fruit with large single seeds.
chest (from the bottom of the ribs to the bottom of the neck) [cf. similar phonotactics of haxxafe ‘side of body, lungs’] [KL ‘lungs’]
bustardsLocal sp. are the white- and perhaps black-bellied bustards
the paired cat-claw thorns of the blackthorn ‘wait-a-bit’ tree
sp. tree (look like acacia, but very tall)
similar to duduyega (this one you do not eat. but M d n know what it is exactly.)
a taciturn person. just sits & listens. may be their character, or just now they’re ill or afraid to speak.
a small tight shrub (gender tall (2–3 m) vs round), of any sp. [Cf. muqqu]
Namaqua dove, Oena capensis. Mom says similar to but not the same bird as utumbu, pace Sands.
Sands/Gudo: Springhare. Gudo has drawing (reddish, long ears) in his book for his Hututume song
an uzame hyena. so named from its ‘huwi’ call.
termitary. Mud from the center (or riverbank) used to make oranakwe dolls, which transpire like actual infants (Skaanes 2015).
words, conversation [no number diff. irreg gender confirmed]
(1) snake(general term).Smaller snakes may not have specific names.(2) [metaphor] undeveloped tubers and edible roots (‘all there are are snakes’ – though these are still eaten);
(Maasai) bushbuckragelaphus scriptus A kill is hephee.

a barrier: cliff, arroyo, river, or ditch you have to go around or climb over, but not a fallen tree. Specifically the Rift WallGram pl for sem. sg or pl; the Rift Wall is almost a mass noun, as from Mangola it stretches across a quarter of the horizon.
the largest local dlapodove, the red-eyed African mourning dove Streptopelia decipiens (perspicillata) [Isaya, Brian].

(1) Sands: mythical beast, smaller than dudugge but bigger than 10 cars at least, has scales like a snake and legs like an elephant. grey/blue in color. Like a brontosaurus. (2)a large unidentified snake, as thick as your leg. Could only be the python, or mythical. [M’s mom gave this for pix of the black mamba and twig snakes.]
breast(s), of a man or woman; udder.
cave, or rock overhang. Esp. if round, as a cave under a boulder. ~ gisawenga [not confirmed? Sands crossed out]
the sun, wife of the moon, the abode of God. By metonymy, God.

(1) sp. snake, likely the OliveGrass snake, Psammophis mossambicus, an active drab-colored back-fanged snake w moderate but non-fatal poison, up to 1½ meters, bites readily per Struik’s.(2) generically ‘snake’, synonymous with iato (but without the latter’s extension to roots).
orb web spider (has a cover on its hole that is like paper. red/brown, dime-sized)

an unattended camp. It may be one that parents have left their children at while foraging, an abandoned camp that may be returned to after several years once food has returned, or a camp permanently abandoned because of death.
a deadfall (a rock propped up by a stick) [Tli’ika term, difficult to confirm in Mangola.]
a name for a running khomati-ko ‘eland’, used when appreciating the beauty of its motion
place outside house to sit around and rest, make fire, or make arrows
sodarub on babies’ gums when they’re teething.
sp. beetle(got for a wood-boring beetle, 8 mm, black, comb-shaped antennae, square abdomen.)
rock hyrax Cape rock hyrax Procavia capensis or yellow-spotted bush hyrax Heterohyrax brucei (diurnal)
tumba fly maggot? fly lays eggs in urine; burrow into your side or arm while you sleep. white, can get fat if left in a long time. squeeze them out.
yellow birds? Isaya: yellow or black & yellow weavers

(1) mother’s brother. a women’s word; may also use kûku, akaye. (2) (as with other Bantu-derived kin terms, someuse it for the reverse relationship: sister’s children, which are usually just waa(ko).)
a large knife, used for butchering
a group, herd, flock, swarm (human, animal (incl. bugs); cannot be used for plants or inanimates) ‘and then we …’Seeka-. [aux] ‘and then we …’Seeka-.
pregnant (or as name for a preg. woman) ‘and then you …’Seeka-. and then he …’Seeka-.
alt. name aardvark osa’i. ‘then she/he/they …’Seeka-. ‘and then he/they …’Seeka-.
rectum (last section of large intestine, full of shit)
a big lake (like Eyasi or Manyara)
women’s rattle, for dancing: a small round calabash with stones in it. No handle; held between two hands. Cf. zzengeno for men
sp. snake. The Isanzu name for cobra, ID’d by Kampala with a cobra. M: same as supe.
a fragrant gum resin used asincense, from the shakwa tree. The Hadza chew it like gum (it’s not hard like acacia gum). By extension, any edible gum, such as bubble gum.
another name for the kumburu water monitor
Sighting/hunting name for male giraffe.‘and then you …’Seeka-. ‘and then he …’Seeka-.
crested francolin‘and then they …’Seeka-. ‘and then they …’Seeka-.
the winged form of hixxiggiko. one of the larger winged termites
sweat bee (doesn’t sting, very small, only produces a handful of honey, which women may collect too, esp. in the west; hives lower down than Apis, and in Commiphora trees)
an arrow with a laurel leaf–shaped metal tip [no poison], or such an arrowhead. Used for small antelope, pig, etc.
river or arroyoregardless of water. fem. is larger than masc.
tuber of a water plantmedicinal, not edible
hole in a tree (such as a baobab) with water. Per W, masc. specifically (or especially?) in baobab.
hole in the ground, incl. animal den
bow; arrows often assumed to be included.
a ‘party’: a bonfire with many people (2 or 3 camps) gathered around, eating, talking, laughing, singing
insect that gives you blisters if it touches you, round and white. lives on animals.
Sands: stork (all storks). Daudi, Isaya: Abdim’s stork Ciconia abdimii.
Sighting/hunting name [M] for a male giraffe (M never h heard pl)
Sands: Verraux’s eagle owl, from nicer picture guide than mine.
a morning star (rises after takino). east of magwanda. same as sháshaé-ko. ‘and then you …’Seeka-.
(sg) ostrich feather; (pl) also ostrich feather headdress worn by men during epeme dance (only called this when used for epeme dance).
a large, solitary uzame spotted hyena. ‘and then they …’Seeka-.
fire(s) built at night, using logs rather than smaller kuni so that the fire lasts until morning.
a small edible tuber. Per Sapo, the plant is small (as your hand?), and the tubers the size of a large chicken egg
alt. name for kukurukukwaye etc. ‘chestnut-bellied sand-grouse’
(1) old man(2) generic term for (great, great-great, …) grandfather or granduncle;
snot, mucus, phlegm (anywhere in body), cold/flu (no other endings possible)
the green pigeon, Treron calva [Isaya]. A kind of dlapo.
sp. bat(esp. large-eared bat, insect eating) kuruma is small, poro large.
a word for tcanjai ‘leopard’ expressing a hunter’s pride, and bravery.
lacertidlizard. The only local species in Struik is Boulenger’s Scrub Lizard, Nucras boulengeri. The prototypical species is evidently somewhat different.
black-backedjackalp. insect, per Sands same as duduyega.
birds that call(1) ‘on’, (2) ‘if/when he ...’. see kwa-.
wellspring‘They’d’ve (said)’, 3fpl. (1) ‘They’d’ve (said)’, 3mpl(2) short for kwahisi ‘if/when they will...’. See kwa-.

oll the traditional name. mix water with earth to make mud; for more elaborate ones, form arms and legs, head, ears, nose, mouth; sew clothes for it; girls around 3–6 yrs carry on their back etc., but many are simple egg shapes, sometimes not even decorated.
plant name; a pale bead made from its stem
a large paper wasp or hornet.

a bright star (several stars elicited)(a) Sirius(b) any of three particularly bright stars in the same part of the sky, incl. Sirius & Canopus (Onkai). Also called takino (Kaunda and Ankiya, but not Onkai or Marta). (c) Venus, as the evening star, only above the western horizon, and only in the evening
rotten (i.e. overripe) baobab fruit (can no longer eat); or just not good to eat

(sg) female excision [half the clitoris], (sg, pl) the girls undergoing it [no name for the ceremony itself, which follows]. This is part of female bonding, in no way enforced by the men, who see it as women’s business. After the cutting (which may be done more than once; that is, a girl may undergo maitoko more than once), the maitobee (or sometimes all the women) turn tables on the men, chasing them with naritcanda, much as the Ituri Mbuti do with switches upon menstruation. So although excision itself may be a Cushitic influence, it may play a part in a far older ritual (Power p.c.). Powerthinks it’s a counter-dominance ritual, balancing out the epheme ceremony, which is run by men, though it only occurs every couple years while an epeme dance may be held several times a month.
stew. originally the water from boiling meat, with or without the meat. now also used for the Tz-style stew eaten with ugali.
earthquake [sg is a single jolt] (seismic tremor only)
any bee-eater, esp. European (dark w yellow throat).
Mangolaone of four regions of Hadza settlement during the dry season.
mushroom (masc. is tall & thin, fem is short & broad).
trunk of elephant or of elephant shrew (of either sp.).
(1) the April-June light rainy season. (2) drizzle
antlion (larva only; adults subsumed under dragonflies).
the stone that’s tossed in girls’ games of qôqoko-ko jacks (place 10 or 20 stones in a bada, throw the mare, take out half or return the half you already have out)
a flat spot on top a hill or mountain.
sp. tree, Vangueria apiculata, syn. V. acutiloba (Woodburn 1970).
(1) of baboons, inside of forearm, palm & fingers. (2) of people, Sands, Malloy: lower arm muscles; M: palm & inside of fingers
a bracelet worn in the past – lots of black bands.
(1) a tuber(2) Sands: plant that grows up, often interlocking in trees, good for starting fires when dry.
wing(s), of insects or birds; shoulder blade(s).
springhare? Unstriped grass rat (Swynnerton). Same as hututume
long, tall baobab cave. Where zzozzozzo bats are found.

leech (Black, lives in water. If you pull it, it just stretches. You smack it to get it off. It’s soft & sucks blood. It can kill animals if they swallow it, as it attaches to the throat.)a man with two wives (no pl) ~ mizzi ‘brother’ (form in Dempwolff, Elderkin)
xiphi­sternum (the pointed bit of cartilage at the base of the sternum)

Acacia melliflora blackthorn (‘wait-a-bit’). a small tree with paired black cat-claw thorns (hoqqoqqo-ko), numerous flowers, med-green small teardrop leaves. Very common in Mangola area. Very hard wood, good for latrine floors.
(1991) speckled pigeon, (1997) green pigeon [y, not hiatus]
a honey bag (leather, for honey only)
your brother, sister, male or female cousin.
prickly pear; fruit eaten, not known that leaves are edible.
umbrella thornThe iconic Serengeti acacia. Long, white, black-tipped thorns as well as cat-claw thorns, tiny oblong light green leaves, twisted seed pods. Very large tree.
a large male lion [Isaya. M thinks it’s a praising form] Called a pic of the Barbary lion this, due to extensive mane.
the largest Hadza habitation in the Mbulu foothills, at the southern end.
round abnormal patch of skin, like Duli & Zai had on their scalps, but it can be anywhere. no blood, doesn’t itch, but hair loss, may have a bug bite in the center.
old, dark, hard honey. prized; it lasts a long time when you chew it.
lant with small white flowers that bees like
a small tree w laurel-like leaves. (fem. ~ short thick trunk)
shrub or small tree with small (½cm) grey-green leaves clustered along woody stems. Leaves chewed to relieve cough.
figfem for both tree and fruit. Tree also hogoyo.
hyoid bones (hard spot under chin; M confirms they are small bones

(1) a 2–3-m shrub/small tree similar to the sasonako. Dark bark and clusters grey-green leaves. A large one in front M’s house. (2) any large tree (e.g. an acacia) when small. [bushes which stay small are tciki-ko/bee.]
Mimosa pigra (used for firewood) [if the leaves sensitive to touch, this is the ‘Giant Sensitive plant’
a musical wood pipe; with holes like a filimbi.S.t. the Hadza make themselves, now rare. Now, people (a few) play marimbako.
Dombeya kirkii ‘river wild pear, river dombeya’ per Marlowe 2010, Woodburn 1970 (Malvaceae, ex Sterculiaceae, a tree
Sands: harrier hawk, goshawk, & shikra, from nicer picture guide than mine.
fertility stick: a decorated stick, often given at birth for initiation ceremonies
a large plant, 1–3-meter blob-like dark green bulb supporting numerous thin succulent branches; may reach 4 m high? poisonous.
boy, girl. almost an erati, still a zzêya. can also be used for adults; the precise meaning is that the person hasn’t yet gone through circumcision ceremony
the king of the jungle (spec. an old male lion? pride of lions?). A boasting name
companion, friend. primarily used between small children. Adults say ncie/ncieko. [hiatus, not y] Cf. nie(ko).
a white grass used to make brooms
a smooth hairless chin, w/o even the hairs some women have (for the Hadza, beard only ever on the chin).
a large paper wasp; makes white paper nests like honeycomb and looks like nondori but doesn’t prey on spiders. same as pikisli.
sp. spider, lives in trees, half dollar sized and white
stringed instrument also used by Datooga.bottom half calabash w stick through it and two (?) wires stretched across like bowstrings. Looks like a banjo; you hit wires with a small stick
ant lion. Cf. marambako (only a little similar, though both lie at the bottom of sand traps for ants.)
baboon(singular or collective ‘a troop of baboons’)work
a blind where hunters wait for animals at water holes.
rope plant. Thick trunk on ground, twining branches climb trees, smooth bark; sprouts baobab-like twigs when on ground. Used for target practice. Same as rutênde.
river, arroyo or natural ditch, regardless of water, or even if it never has water in it. But can’t be used for a man-made ditch.
(1) (masc) bee pupae. no coll(2) fem) raisin: naturally dried
a mane standing up on the head all the way down the back, as on a zebra, giraffe, warthog.
single strand of beads w a circle, rootworn on head
ball and socket joint of hips
sp. dhaman Purple flowers, yellow berries. Berries eaten raw, or boiled as ‘tea’ / porridge. Leaves eaten boiled.
brother, sister, cousin, relative of same generation, and by extension friend. Little girls call each other this.
scent gland(s) (e.g. dikdik, galago, civet, ratel)
upper leg bone (femur) or upper arm bone (humerus);
a kind of harpoon used for hunting dikdik and other animals — you cut off part of an arrow and tie it back on again.
the serval (Looks like a cross between a cat and a cheetah.)
p. bee (doesn’t sting, fairly small, produces lots of honey – it fills the hive )
knurling (the barbs on a metal arrow head, or the cross-spiral scoring cut into the business end of a wooden bird arrow to make it hold fast in the bird.) (The barb attached to wooden arrows is roo)
star(s)Children of the sun and moon.
sp. antelope, ‘looks like a young impala’.
a bowl, whether a half-calabash or baobab pod. Used, among other things, to collect berries.
(1)  a little child(2) salt with soda in it
(gender per shape, tall vs squat) largest of acacias, no thorns. The Hadza used to leave offerings made of grass for the ancestors at these trees.
ochre? a red earth used for body paint.
the flying phase of a large termite, about the size of a large hornet. Eaten (abdomen only)
cricket (one that digs and makes lot of noise: “tsiiiiiiiiii”)
baby, infant (can’t yet crawl). msg only.
his wife. Cf. ome her husband.
her husband. Cf. oko-ko his wife.
bushbuck. Isaya: similar to but larger than the indofêda bushbuck
sp. sebesten,cordia, manjack, glue berry, clammy cherry,esp. Cordia sinensis ~ gharaf, the ‘grey-leaved saucerberry’The major berry staple of the Hadza, esp. in Mangola.
the (adult) martialeagle and black-chested snake eagle Circaetus pectoralis in flight

Sands: infant/toddler (a child before they get to walking around well, their fontanel still moves, 0–3 yrs?) Mariam: as old as 15, if before puberty. Marlowe: from birth to 4 or 5. Crittenden (p.c.): crawling or toddling.
birdlime: gum put on trees used to catch birds (the gum can be from any tree) pl for several places [no VH]
aardvarkOrycteropus afer. (its den may be used as a convenient place for burying the dead, not just for ‘important’ people.)

fire-block: the base of wood used with a miseko fire-drill. A hole is cut with a notch in the side for the sawdust to spill out; a bit of grit may be added to get things started. the sawdust and eventually ember is caught on a knife blade, bottle cap, or the like.
a large tree with light bark.
baby sling (cloth used to carry a baby on one’s back)
a hole in a tree (behive only?) too small or narrow to reach in, and too deep to use an axe to widen, so a stick has to be used to pull out (tluku) the honey.
Desert Rose, Adenium obesum, used for arrow poison.
hip (top of the pelvis). Sands: the hip bones that flare out (innominate bone TBW)
baldness – front, top, or whole head
plant used to treat fever/malaria. a small dense bush with many thin very white very sharp spines, and pretty orange-cream 5-petaled flowers. Very common in Mangola.
a respectful term for father, paternal uncle.
a pipe made out of shakwako-tree heartwood.
clitoris and hood; cut out at maito-ko excision
an edible tuber found in Mangola & Tli’ika.
your grandmother, grand-aunt, granddaughter, grand-niece, or more distant generations. See akatchoko-ko.
sp. tree w berries kids like. Lobate leaves, ends twigs thorn-like, and twigs bear thorns.
your (great) grand-father, grand-uncle, maternal uncle; by extention, (great) grand-son, grand-nephew [but not nephew]. See akhwa.
east. cf. diroda-bee. these are not common words.
sp. paper wasps. listed under pisli.
scorpion (the one with the very bad sting)
impala  One of the principal large game species, and an epeme animal.[unconfirmed] (poqowiyakodescribes an egg half-in, half-out of a bowl lying on its side: Lev. CNT-5)
poison applicator: small stick for daubing poison on an arrow head.
baobab flour (both the soft sour powder in the pod the seeds are packed in and the ground seeds)
Sands: sp. orchid; a purple spotted plant that comes out after the rains. The big round root kids use as a doll
the only local viper, the puff adder
Sighting / hunting  name of the tarishi secretary bird
(1) praying mantis(2) a certain (spirit) seen in dreams. not of ancestors. bad.(3) back of the head (area of occipital bone) Cf. qoqoroma.
(1) Sands: harrier hawk, from nicer photo book than mine.(2) mushroom. (some are eaten.)
Namaqua dove. A kind of dlapo. sooty chat, anteater chat? (named for call)

(1992) sooty chat, anteater chat? (named for call) to hang swaying (to hang so that it can sway – like fruit on a tree, or a belt on a hook on the wall, or clothes drying on a line, but not a picture on the wall.)mong the Hadza, a ‘big’ person, whether from age, size, wit, etc. The word is used for a primary person or leader among outsiders; the Hadza have no such people.severe pains, as made K cry out when he had pneumonia with TBboils? They grow, may be few, but sometimes whole face is covered. some may hurt, & hurt a lot if you squeeze it & it is not readyto come out.to bend/fold one’s legs.immaturetubers~ qonga ‘hare’cut it.ignorant or stupid, but without being crazyto remove obj from cooking rocks (only for cooking)See qhe.to jump overSands: upper arm muscles to carry, supported underneath by the handSee qhe.to die/kill/fight together in large numbersto decorate to be in a hurry. to act, to pretend, as hunting and making bows & arrows for tourists, but not when they’re not around.to continue, keep doing.to cut once, into two; cf. qhoo to cut up.be right-side upbent, turned up, curvedsee qhe ‘cut’Sands: sp. orchid; a purple spotted plant that comes out after the rains. The big round root kids use as a dolllame (can’t walk at all)the only local viper, the puff adderv.t. to have an abundance, to get a lotpeaked, as a mountainroot of qhoo ‘to cut up’ and plur qhoko (qho‹ko›) ‘to slash’to scratch (to ‘itch’ an itch)to cut up, chop up(1) to shoot (arrows, gun, slingshot (but not traditional slingSighting / hunting  name of the tarishi secretary bird to pierce, to poke a hole in.(1) praying mantis(2) a certain (spirit) seen in dreams. not of ancestors. bad.(3) back of the head (area of occipital bone) Cf. qoqoroma.to ask for, to beg.(1) Sands: harrier hawk, from nicer photo book than mine.(2) mushroom. (some are eaten.) to split, to be split. the sound of something falling (rock, fruit.)to squat~ qhobomburi, Sighting/hunting name of the tarishi secretary birdto wear out, of clothes. (worn to the point that if you pull on them, they tear)the remnantsthe small bits left when others have already taken the good pieces. to bend or fold.to disappearNamaqua dove. A kind of dlapo.

sooty chat, anteater chat? (named for call) to be fullto zoom (venitive or andative compound required)mim. of s.o. being knocked down.aughing dove without neck band, such as Streptopelia (Stigmatopelia) senegalensis. A kind of dlapo ‘dove’. ~ xxaggatcha become thin the hard palateWhite peopleblisters.shooting star, meteor (including very bright ones)the last person to finish in a race(bare root unattested)  soft, or a baby born the other day (a few days only), from the soft head, bones, skin.to lift upklipspringer~qqapijja ‘emaciated’to go blind(v.t.) to sew thread, clothes (cf. ate to string beads); to go (walk, run, fly) side-by-sideto be emaciated, just skin & bonesthe red lining that sticks out of the anus when defecating; sticks out all the time on a baboon [not the whole rectum] [basic def ~ baboon’s ass?](1) to find s.t. you’re searching for(2) to come down with a sudden fevergeneral term for lizardv.i. to be sleepyto push w the heada beetle, ≈ 2cm, with rounded ridged carapace, rather like a cross between a weevil and a Calif. stinkbug. Common in the Baray camps. to hit, to beathartebeestSands (1997) the labia & vagina. M: same as akho-ko
the smaller sp. hare (whiter in color)
Sands: sp. ant(?) that likes to go into water. they don’t bite (Sands: tailor or cocktail ants? from pix)
a swing (normally a vine swing), for children or adults.
the soft palate, uvula, & other soft parts in the throat
the last person to finish in a race
aughing dove without neck band, such as Streptopelia (Stigmatopelia) senegalensis. A kind of dlapo ‘dove’.
shooting star, meteor (including very bright ones)
the red lining that sticks out of the anus when defecating; sticks out all the time on a baboon [not the whole rectum] [basic def ~ baboon’s ass?]
a beetle, ≈ 2cm, with rounded ridged carapace, rather like a cross between a weevil and a Calif. stinkbug. Common in the Baray camps.
Sands (1997) the labia & vagina. M: same as akho-ko [unconfirmed] Sands, from Elderkin: ‘to crack a bit’ (egg only); what a bird does when it hatches.
(1) bell-like seed-pod rattle(2) Per Skaanes 2017, the khomati ‘eland’ is euphemistically referred to as seseme or qqingiribii when shot (and of course hubuee).
beeswax (after squeezing out the honey), earwax. Not used for commercial wax, which the Hadza do not know.
s.o. with a badly healed broken bone (leg, arm, jaw, etc.), so called because they don’t have full use of it.

a blunt arrow, made of a higgo (bird arrow) with something blunt stuck on the end. Trad. this was a corn cob (usutuko), but now large bolt nuts are also used (screwed on). Used to shoot birds; the blunt end can break a wing.
a shrub/small tree with thick trunk, branches, & twigs, a bit like a Plumeria, with clusters of leaves at tips. Milky sap & 2cm wild fig-like fruit. Poisonous
knobkerrie. Thickened at one end (otherwise it’s mu’a-ko). Used to hunt hyrax (kept in hand), or birds on ground (thrown as they take flight). Used for the clubs of the Maasai & Datooga.
sp. fruit (common in Mangola): ~ mencerekwahi, slukwaae(1992) sooty chat, anteater chat? (named for call)
mong the Hadza, a ‘big’ person, whether from age, size, wit, etc. The word is used for a primary person or leader among outsiders; the Hadza have no such people.
severe pains, as made K cry out when he had pneumonia with TB
boils? They grow, may be few, but sometimes whole face is covered. some may hurt, & hurt a lot if you squeeze it & it is not ready
kidney(s). the bean-shaped organs themselves (other words ~ the general area).
Sighting/hunting name for nee male(?) baboon. Cf. robe.
a tree like mkuyu from which rafabii (bark thread) is obtained.
a herd, flock, swarm, group (animals, people, bugs, but not inanimates)
Suway [10 yr old]’s name for rokwarokwa.
a stump (still standing; if branches are coming out of it then it’s a ‘tree’).
skink (generic name). Gudo uses it for those skinks he doesn’t call qqanda, Sundevall’s and Variable. Isaya also says it’s a skink, and points out the short legs: the Short-necked,
sp. Small tree, has white flowers in the summer.
(1) pipestone: a smooth soft stone used for carving dlomasabee pipes(2)gum, or gum-producing tuber?
joint (of body or of a thing).
a sighting/hunting name for neeko baboon; often used as a name for a troop of baboons. Cf. rabe.
shield. not used by the Hadza.
cave, hole (masc. larger, fem. smaller. ~ a hole in any direction); also water hole
dirty water, as in a water hole when the water is almost all gone.
female rock hyrax past child-bearing age.
wooden barb; horns — the long ones, such as those of gazelle, oryx, kudu.
Sighting/hunting name for the tlhakate rhinoceros. [from next]
a small awl (used to bore holes in pipe or arrow shafts)
the xxana poisoned arrow, or such an arrowhead
the short thin very spiny cactus that grows in patches. used as an eye medicine.
puddle, like those in the road
(aorta: Elderkin) (1997) (Gudo) muscle on outside of thigh that links thigh to hip; and sinew that ‘grabs the kidneys’ up to the heart
lukuchuko, a gambling game of pure chance played by taking turns tossing a ‘mother’ disk and two smaller maribii ‘child’ disks to ‘eat’ (win) an ati ante.
ladle (baobab pod with a handle). used to drink water.sp. bee (doesn’t sting, produces medium amounts of honey)
windpipe, trachea. incl. Adam’s apple. same as nkoro.
disease where neck glands swell up big. contagious, and in glands under jaw. fever, but you won’t die. not mumps? (not in cheeks)
fish, as food (not a Hadza custom, tho the Hz will eat catfish trapped in pools when the occasion presents itself), at least for Mariam, as she does not consider ccama, ccara to be ‘serious’ words.
swallow/swift/marins w curved wings in flight.
swallows/martins/swifts w straight wings in flight. swift? swallow?
a pouch worn around the neck to carry tobacco, beads
a place name (near Yaeda Chini) [Hadza name]
alt. name for elephant. Get this sometimes with pic, as in Lonely Planet TZ.
a plant used to counteract witchcraft.
(1) tuberculosis (coughing disease where you cough blood and for a long time) (2) sp. insect, looks like a medium sized black ant but fliesquietly?
a piece or strip of cloth. Smaller than dlo’a.
various diseases. (smelly yellow pus discharge from genitals & armpits, pus fills insides of thighs so you can’t walk.)
moon, moonlight, month. Husband of isho-ko the sun.
(1) other Africans(2) carnivore about the size of a small genet [M], ID’d for the eastern golden cat
sp. cordia? One of several minor food berries that resemble & are commonly called ondoshibi.
single person: bachelor, widow(er): alone in life – not married
strips (rings?) of fur to wrap around bow
dear, sweetheart, my love – a term used especially by newlyweds
sheath (for a knife) fem. is basic, masc. used for a long knife.
1997) spleen (Sands ID’d on a goat; the organ that gets hard w malaria. ~ makasita, puche.)
s.o. who tells lies in order to cause strife(by)ourselves – see sî.
he largest river feeding Lake Eyasi, flowing from west to east into SW end lake.
metal armband or bracelet. KL says they were adopted from the Maasai.
tree with thick foliage. lactating women crush bark into water and drink (boil & drink froth?) to make their milk ‘clean’
one of four regions of Hadza settlement during the dry season
costal cartilage: the cartilaginous part attaching the ribs to the sternum

scar (from purposeful cuts, not scars from the burns children make on their arms on purpose (nothing to do, so they burn polka dots on their bodies: let embers burn down to the skin. not a display of bravery.)
back, of torso, from neck to pelvis.
a tree, at least 4m high (the one I saw), w all branches <3cm diam.
a multi-barbed arrow (multiple small barbs down each side of metal arrow head, whether or not there is a blade at the tip or just a point)

(1) larvae of fly of Mycetophilidae family (fungus gnats). Tiny, translucent grubs with a black dot. They are gregarious and when traveling together at first looks like a single ≈ 10-cm creature (snake)(2) sp. tree, ‘looks like a Christmas tree’. Marta’s camp is named after it.
family of plants, includes the one with small leaves, pretty blue-purple flowers, also one with white flowers (not utilized for anything)
bone marrow (by)myself – see sô.(by)himself – see sô.
pimples, zits, rash. Sg is collective, pl yet more.
shoulder(s). the area of the shoulder joint.
thread (cotton)Sands, from Elderkin: small paper wasps, live in groups of about 20
the largest Hadza habitation in Dunduina,
[Dunduina dialect] Maasai, a traditional enemy at the northern end of Hadza territory. Cf. qqunguwe.
rope, belt, strap, as for ankle rattles. (thick)
Sirius (Kaunda, Onkai, Ankiya). Venus as the evening star (Isaya). Synonymous with magwanda by some (see).

an annual plant, 1½ m, w clusters of 1½-cm burrs that have so spines packed so tight they are almost solid (almost like a wild cucumber), though the two at the tip are larger and look a bit like the pincers of an earwig.
bee larva. eaten live, usually but not always with their little remaining honey.
sp. bush. fairly common in Mangola.
Sands: big veins and arteries of the chest — aorta, etc (that go from the heart to the windpipe?)
a children’s game: they spin around until they get dizzy & fall down. [no other meaning; no conscious morphology]
the fine (sinew) thread used to tie on the fletching. not used for stringing beads.
the call of the little bee-eater?to run
bushes, thicket. many sp small, round bush; as tall as M’s waist. Not used for small trees
the lower back / upper butt area; back of pelvis (of people),
the softer metals, incl. gold. Arrow heads used to be made of tcôma, but are now tcûma.
another name for mazzu. (those making this identification deny that mazzu is the same animal as rora.)
men of old who used clubs and ran
sp. bird, looks a bit like the grassland pipit.
hole in tree, with or w/o bees. Deep is masc.
space between anus & genitals (perineum/taint) [human], space between the anus and tail [animal]
a clearing outside the camp (an area without brush or trees).
aardwolf ‘a kind of striped hyena; eats termites from mound, & other bugs, as well as meat.’
car (shaped like a tortoise, used in days past)
a large striped hyena (not nec. solitary or male)
wrist guard worn on left hand. A sign of bravery.
(1997) redstart, rufous sparrowto carry & put down many times
bolide? Sands: meteor/comet (or it’s hole?) Onkai: shooting star (s.t. about destroying the world if it lands?)
rift, cleft, gorge. also used for a large vagina (large hole).
small termite, eat wood & houses. fliers not eaten

a hole in a baobab (not just any tree), low to the ground, that you need to bend or sit down to stick your arm in (a higher hole you stand or have to climb for is thao-ko). must be big enough for your arm, though this may only be because you chopped it open; with or without bees.
aloe (M has some out front. there are various kinds.)
one of four regions of Hadza settlement during the dry season
(1) metal bracelet worn in the past; also name of the metal. Thick Datooga bracelets are called this. (2) Rufous elephant shrew
Sands (1991, same as zzerere) blacksmith plover, black-winged stilt, avocet, sanderling, greenshank
bullet cartridge. used for carrying sewing needles or dawa. People may be afraid to show these, as guns are illegal.
winged fly whose maggots dig into the skin
tobacco. Fem is ground tobacco, masc. the loaf mkate sold at market.
heel, up to back of ankle
lid (for tobacco horn, calabash, etc., incl. Swahili pots)
sp. cordia? One of several minor food berries that resemble and are commonly called ondoshi
(1)(wild greens, mucilaginous when cooked)(2)Sands: sp. mouse, likes to live in holes in the rocks. K’s camp, Mom, M all reject this]
the hedgehogNamed for its small size
person/people (used collectively). no fem. except for gram. agreement
piglet. (Isaya: young of warthog or bushpig until reaches height of mother’s belly.)
[coll -ko] spotted (laughing) hyenaCrocuta crocuta. Hadza are not supposed to eat it, because it eats the Hadza dead when it can, and it is not hunted, but it may be eaten when convenient.
(1) boy child in general (one of a fewgeneric kin terms that can take simple plurals in ‘good’ Hadza, but without a kinship meaning)(2) son, nephew, grandson or son-in-law
mouse (smaller one; lives underground and does not climb walls or roofs)
abdominal cavity. The place inside not including the organs.
(1) root (general term)(2) a dry xxekwa tuber. Not good for food or drink.
the long flicking tail of a bird, i.e. a flycatcher
frog, toad. generic term. no specific names.
long-legged trousers (only when worn by men. no word for when worn by women.)
chalk, limestone(?); the earth you use to make mako pots
spark. the ember you get fire-drilling, also sparks that jump from fire or hammering iron or rock.
forked stick (whether used as an arrow stand or a porridge stirrer) or the poles used to build a house

leavingssp. tree [not used for anything]rainbow(1) to flee, of multiple sbj. (to run very fast, ordinarily when trying to escape, but per M could use for Olympic sprinters.)(2) to chase (with arrows or spears only, not a stick: that is tle’a)to spy? to hide oneself (a bit, as behind a tree) so that others won’t see you but you can see them.(may be either xhini or xhê-ne)to be crowded, to be full (of people) (got this from Marta for Isaya’s xiiti ‘hoopoe’. Same as Mom’s xîti?)to be overwhelmed? not able to walk properly? (on your knees from illness, or staggering under a load)to die offor be finished in large numbers.a creeping morning-glory-like vine.to clutch.to stoke (feed) a fire (add wood so it burns well).(1) to stand still(2) to peg down a fresh skin to stretch & dry it; of the skins, to be dry/ready for use.to leak, trickle, drip(1)  mosquito(2) malaria [the identity existed per KL in 1935]to prod(get obj up, etc.)vagina (only the opening, not everything) to chop (trees). no do (only takes tree objects, no obj affix nec.) to bend downDaudi: Verreauxs’ eagle,to throw, also to discard.~ xoo ‘wash’(1) to open, (i.e. door, button, book).(2) a field, in the sense of clearing brush. to become thin, emaciated, just skin and bones, whether through age or disease.to quit fighting [confirmed by Mom] to shoot an arrowa scar, from accidents only, not cry cuts or intentional burns a “male” (one-barb) poison arrow, or such an arrow head.(1) to dry (intrans.).See xxape.s.o. with good aimliver (of animal or person) ~ xoo ‘wash’ankle (outer and inner)the leguminous vinepick (fruit), take down to change from one situation to another, or to leave a situation, such as leaving traditional foods for ugali. ~ xoo ‘wash’semen (no other endings)fang.to stuff, to be stuffed (from eating)fang(s)to wash (DO oblig.)same as xxexxôkwa, qqoqqôkwa, qqeqqôkwa. [Pear Story pt 3, l 32] [not getting this variant to check asp.]hill; to gnaw at (bones, etc.)voice, as in a singing voice. to washto wear jewelrySolifuge. See under nxashi.to daub on arrow poison with a poroggo.
(1)  mosquito(2) malaria [the identity existed per KL in 1935]
glowing coal, ember: pieces of glowing wood
peg, piton (a short, sharp stick, pounded into trunk to climb a tree (esp. baobab) for honey, birds, or eggs.)
a scar, from accidents only, not cry cuts or intentional burns a “male” (one-barb) poison arrow, or such an arrow head.
voice, as in a singing voice.
a large grassy valley parallel to Lake Eyasi. Game-rich and swampy during the wet.‘and then I/we/you/they …’Seeya-.
male, human or animal. may be used for ‘he’s a real man’?
a bit o’ rain.‘and then you …’Seeya-. ‘and then he/she/they …’Seeya-. ‘and then they/he …’Seeya-. ‘and then I …’Seeya-.
alt name for pofu. short for iyaderera.
(1) way, path, road.(2) way, manner, behavior.
a general term for mouse, rat
raised dust; also fog as in Arusha, which is rare here
a clam or its shell; a clam shell used as a spoon (e.g. for baobab porridge).
a poisonedforeshaft & arrow head, or an arrow with one.
a spring, incl. a well dug in sand; maybe 1 or 2?m for Hadza, but for Datooga may be much deeper.
(long thin) tail, i.e. of vervet monkey, baboon, lion, mongoose, rat, sheep, cat, cheetah, leopard
digging stick, yam-stick (made from any tree, commonly Cordia, Dombeya, Grewia). Pointy end for digging & levering rocks; flat-cut end for chopping roots. Pointy end fire hardened.
white spot(s) on adult rock hyrax (Sands); a white stripe down the back, as hyrax or bushpig (Isaya & Gisalonga) [could be either for M]
a large tree; all branches are soft inside & small ones are bored out in June for drinking straws or musical pipes. Bees make honey from the flowers.
child, kid, able to speak and walk, up to puberty. [say 3–16 yrs] Older than ora, younger than dlakweko/erati. Crittenden (pc): young child to middle childhood.
maraca: a gourd with a long neck used during epeme dance, e.g. as a decorated one used to hold epeme (eland) grease
bird: any small bird. It tends to be elicited for birds which do not have specific names.
diaphragm [Elderkin & Sands have stomach fat as well. Perhaps confusion is from same word being used for both cartilage and fat?]
a small insect (very little, ruins crops)
sp. cordia? One of several minor food berries
ny of 3 unidentified birds w diff coloration
a large lake, as Eyasi, Manyara
Sands: a certain eye disease where the eye becomes white.
cataract. a pathological white spot on theeye.
